caption.center: WALDEN v. S. M. WHITNEY COMPANY INC.

opinion.opinion_text:
1. A bill of exceptions will not be dismissed because a party in the trial court who is not interested in the judgment excepted to is not made a party defendant in error.
2. Where one of the defendants in error when the case was previously before this court (who was a plaintiff in the trial court) voluntarily dismissed his action in the trial court, and on motion of such defendant in error the writ of error in this court was dismissed because the case had become moot, it was an abuse of discretion for the trial court, in the absence of any reason therefor appearing in the record, to tax against the plaintiff in error the costs of bringing the case to this court.
No. 15430. JUNE 4, 1946. REHEARING DENIED JULY 5, 1946.Page 66
opinion.posture: Motion to tax costs. Before Judge Humphrey. Jefferson Superior Court. December 26, 1945.
opinion.opinion_text:
The exception in this case is to a judgment assessing costs in an equitable proceeding. S. M. Whitney Company, a corporation, filed in Jefferson Superior Court, against M. C. Barwick, Mrs. Bessie Kate Walden, and others, an equitable petition to enjoin the prosecution of conflicting actions respecting title to and liens on certain bales of cotton held by Whitney Company as a warehouseman. To an interlocutory order granting an injunction and interpleader, Mrs. Walden excepted naming Whitney Company and M. C. Barwick defendants in error. While the case was pending in this court Whitney Company voluntarily dismissed its action in the trial court, and filed a motion here to dismiss the writ of error because the case had become moot. Mrs. Walden responded to the motion and insisted that, if this court should dismiss the writ of error on the ground urged, then it should assess, for the use of the officers of the trial court, all the costs accrued in bringing the case to this court. In an opinion dismissing the writ of error on the ground that the case had become moot this court said in part: "The matter of taxing costs accruing in the superior court is within the jurisdiction of that court, and will not be decided by this court except on review," and "this court will not decide a case solely to determine the matter of costs advanced in this court." Walden v. S. M. Whitney Co.,200 Ga. 6 (36 S.E.2d 157).
After the return of the remittitur to the trial court, Mrs. Walden moved that the judgment of the Supreme Court be made the judgment of the trial court, and that the costs of carrying the case to this court, including costs of the transcript of record and the bill of exceptions and costs of the Supreme Court, be taxed against Whitney Company.
The trial court entered a judgment making the judgment of the Supreme Court the judgment of the trial court, but taxing the costs against Mrs. Walden. The exception is to this judgment.
opinion.attorneys:
Casey Thigpen, for plaintiff.
Gordon Lanier and Albert G. Ingram, for defendant.
opinion.opinion_byline: ATKINSON, Justice. (After stating the foregoing facts.)
opinion.opinion_text:
1. A motion was filed in this court by Whitney Company to dismiss the writ of error, on the ground that M. C. Barwick, one of the original defendants in the trial court, and a defendant in error when thePage 67 case was previously before the Supreme Court, is not named a defendant in error, and that Barwick is interested in sustaining the judgment taxing costs against Mrs. Walden, since any judgment for costs in favor of Mrs. Walden would be a charge against both of the original defendants in error.
There is no merit in the motion to dismiss the writ of error. The only exception now under review is to a judgment overruling a motion of Mrs. Walden to tax against Whitney Company the costs of previously taking the case to the Supreme Court, and taxing the costs against the movant. A bill of exceptions will not be dismissed because a party in the trial court who is not interested in the judgment excepted to is not made a party defendant in error. Code, ยง 6-1202; Johnson v. Giraud,191 Ga. 577 (13 S.E.2d 365). While Barwick was an original party in the case, the question of whether the costs should be taxed against him was not raised by the motion to tax costs against Whitney Company, and therefore he was not a necessary party to the present bill of exceptions.
2. While in all civil actions at law, "except as otherwise provided, the party who shall discontinue, fail, or be cast in such suit shall be liable for the costs thereof" (Code, ยง 24-3401; Board of Education of Madison County v. Fowler,192 Ga. 35 (14 S.E.2d 478), under our statutes in equity cases "it is the province of the judge . . to determine upon whom the costs shall fall (Code, ยง 37-1105; Bush v. Little, 171 Ga. 206 (2) 154 S.E. 886), and "this court will not interfere unless [his] discretion has been abused." Hicks v. Atlanta TrustCo., 187 Ga. 314 (2), 315 (200 S.E. 301), and citations;Fitzgerald v. Vaughan, 189 Ga. 707 (3), 711 (7 S.E.2d 78);Sangster v. Toledo Manufacturing Co., 193 Ga. 685 (7) (19 S.E.2d 723).
This case being in equity, the only question is whether the trial court abused its discretion in taxing the costs. When the case was previously before this court, Whitney Company, plaintiff in the trial court and one of the defendants in error in the previous proceeding, voluntarily dismissed its action in the trial court, and on motion of Whitney Company the writ of error in this court was dismissed because the case had become moot. It thus appears that the plaintiff in error in the instant case, through no fault upon her part, was deprived of having the assignments of error in her bill of exceptions passed upon by this court. The record contains nothingPage 68 to show why the costs were assessed against the instant plaintiff in error and not taxed against the party who voluntarily dismissed his action. Therefore it was an abuse of discretion for the trial court to tax against the plaintiff in error the costs of bringing the previous case to the Supreme Court. Hamilton v.DuPre, 103 Ga. 795 (30 S.E. 248); Mendenhall v. Stovall,191 Ga. 452 (2) (12 S.E.2d 589).
Judgment reversed. All the Justices concur.
